A and D are correct. When a Flex application runs in AIR, you can control whether the application uses the Flex drag manager or the AIR drag manager. There are several differences between the Flex and AIR drag managers, for example, with AIR, the dragEnter event triggers many times when you drag an item over any component, even if the component is not a valid drop target. No custom drop animations can be used. The operating system handles the behavior of the cursor and the drag image.

item.question: which are the true statements while using the AIR Drag Manager as opposed to the Flex drag manager? Choose two:
item.answer: dragEnter event triggers many times even if the component is not a valid drop target
dragEnter event triggers many times only when you drag an item over a valid drop target
DragProxy class animates the drag image based on the results of the drop

question.feedback: B and C are correct. The FlexNativeMenu component defines two specific events, both of which dispatch event objects that are instances of the FlexNativeMenuEvent class. FlexNativeMenuEvent.ITEM_CLICK is dispatched when a user selects an enabled menu item of type normal or check. This event is not dispatched when a user selects a menu item that opens a submenu or a disabled menu item. FlexNativeMenuEvent.MENU_SHOW is dispatched when the entire menu or a submenu opens, including a top-level menu of an application or window menu.

question.feedback: C is correct. Lightweight windows have no chrome and do not appear on the Windows task bar or the Mac OS X window menu. In addition, lightweight windows do not have the System (Alt+Space) menu on Windows. Lightweight windows are suitable for notification bubbles and controls such as combo-boxes that open a short-lived display area. When the lightweight type is used, systemChrome must be set to none.
